column1: An exoplanet or extrasolar planet is a planet that orbits a star other than the Sun. Starting in 1988
column5: 623 planetary systems and 592 multiple planetary systems confirmed. HARPS (since 2004) has discovered about a hundred exoplanets while the Kepler space telescope (since 2009) has found more than two thousand. Kepler has also detected a few thousand candidate planets
column6: of which about 11% may be false positives. On average
column7: there is at least one planet per star
column8: with a percentage having multiple planets. About 1 in 5 Sun-like stars have an "Earth-sized" planet in the habitable zone
column9: with the nearest expected to be within 12 light-years distance from Earth. Assuming 200 billion stars in the Milky Way
column10: that would be 11 billion potentially habitable Earth-sized planets in the Milky Way
column11: rising to 40 billion if planets orbiting the numerous red dwarfs are included.
